results.title: Another way = Egymasra nezve
results.creator_credit: Karoly Makk, Mafilm and Dialog Filmstudio
results.brief_description: Set in the oppressive period of communist rule following the 1956 uprising in Hungary, this film focuses on the connections between political and sexual repression. Eva, an outspoken journalist at a state-controlled newspaper becomes attracted to Livia, a married colleague. Her self-expression as a writer and a lesbian is crushed by the state but she refuses to stay silent. As the relationship between the women deepens, they are no longer prepared to limit the expression of their love for each other to clandestine trysts. Livia’s defiance of her husband and Eva’s defiance of the state brings about a tragic end to a love affair that was doomed from the outset. A politically courageous, touching and intelligent plea for tolerance by Hungary’s best known director, based on the semi-autobiographical bestselling novel by his co-scriptwriter Erzsebet Galgoczi. Cast includes Jadwiga Jankowska-Cieslak, Grazyna Szapolowska and Josef Kroner. In Hungarian with English subtitles.

results.title: Another viewpoint
results.brief_description: Intended for prospective migrants to Australia from Europe. Shows the reactions and impressions of various immigrants. It is emphasised that Australia is a predominantly suburban society.

results.title: Another Tuesday night
results.creator_credit: Lynn Hegarty, Mark Gould and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Married women who are in paid jobs spend an average 36 hours a week on unpaid household work, whereas married men do an average of 18.1/2 hours a week of unpaid work. This dramatised story explores one family’s conflict of sharing the load between both partners working fulltime and the responsibility of running a home and caring for their young daughter. On this particular Tuesday evening, Bridget (Karen Vickery), tired and rather tense, finally turns on her partner Mark (Richard Healy) over the matter of washing the dishes. She feels he is not sharing the full burden of domestic duties preferring to participate in the easier and more pleasant tasks and leaving her to the real housework such as cleaning the toilet, preparing dinner and doing the dishes. What is fair to both in balancing and sharing paid work, housework and childcare? Booklet included with video.

results.title: Another side of the forest = L'Autre visage de la foret
results.creator_credit: Strowan Robertson, Raoul Fox, Colin Low, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A fascinating look at developments that aim to protect and conserve Canada’s vast forest reserves. Some of the experiments shown, both in laboratories and in the field include turning a Newfoundland bog into woodland, propagating British Columbia seedlings to withstand mechanical planting, inoculating Ontario elms against bark beetle and devising ways to control fire.
results.title_for_label: Another side of the forest = L’Autre visage de la foret

results.title: Another kind of music
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Yates, Glen Salzman and Fruits and Roots
results.brief_description: The story of four people from very different backgrounds, who are drawn together by their love of music. This simple story-line based around reggae music is designed to stimulate ideas on multiculturalism by emphaszing positive contributions of different cultures.

results.title: Another girl, another planet
results.creator_credit: Michael Almereyda, Bob Gosse, Robin O'hara and Kabu Productions
results.brief_description: Another girl another planet has the distinction of being shot entirely in ‘Pixelvision’ (PXL), a now defunct Fisher Price kids video camera, initially made famous by Milwaukee teen artist Sadie Benning. The grainy, low light, high contrast, black and white images this inexpensive camera creates lends the film a casual home movie style, an appropriate mood for the film’s languid musings about love and relationships. Although the images border on the abstract at times, “Another girl another planet” has a clearly defined narrative. The film traces the loves and angst of East Village neighbours, the morose and commitment phobic Bill (Barry Sherman) and the married highly strung Nic (Nic Ratner). Director Michael Almereyda resurrected the ‘pixelvision’ camera once again for his eerie 1994 revisionist vampire film Nadja. Cast includes Elina Lowensohn, Mary B. Ward, Isabel Gilles.

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for Aboriginal Australians to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work whereas traditional Aborigines did not recognise the western idea of work and preferred to follow their own cultural identity. Then came the mission stations, removal of Aboriginal children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when black Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: Another day of healing
results.creator_credit: Graham Bye, Leon Bram, Film Partnership (Vic.) and Associated World
results.brief_description: In an attempt to cater for the medical needs of over 200,000 people annually, the Austin Hospital works twenty-four hours a day. The film shows the activities of all the departments of the Hospital and briefly tells some of its history. Written by John Hindle.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Bye, Leon Bram, Film Partnership (Vic.) and Associated World

results.title: Another day in paradise
results.creator_credit: Larry Clark, James Woods, Stephen Chin and Chinese Bookie pictures
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, Larry Clark’s offbeat road movie delves into familiar territory for the always controversial director, that being the search for or absence of a familial or communal maxim. Based on a novel by Eddie Little, “Another day in paradise” follows the misadventures of two young criminal lovers and part-time junkies Bobbie and Rosie (Vincent Kartheiser and Natasha Gregson Wagner) who team up with the more experienced crime couple Mel and Sid (James Woods and Melanie Griffith) to commit a series of robberies across America. Bobbie, coming from a seriously dysfunctional family (with hints of physical abuse from his father), begins to form a strong familial bond with the childless Mel and Sid. The ‘happy families’ scenario begins to come apart however when the crew begin to get more reckless with their crimes, while falling heavier into drug use. Larry Clark (whose past photographic essays on teenagers inform most of his film work), adopts his usual languid style as the camera casually drifts over young bodies, their boredom only slightly elevated by sporadic bursts of violence. In contrast, James Woods gives his familiar intense performance, while Melanie Griffith imbues her role with a unselfconscious charm as the junkie substitute ‘mother’ for this ill-fated family. Cast includes: Lou Diamond Philips, Peter Sarsgaard.
